key_insight: State-of-the-art vision-language models (VLMs) can act as reliable perceptual judges, replicating binary human preferences for image quality and enabling compression models to be optimized for human-aligned perception instead of naive pixel-wise losses.
problem_solved: Traditional distortion metrics (e.g., MSE) and bespoke perceptual nets are poorly aligned with human judgments and/or require costly psychophysical datasets; the paper addresses the need for scalable, accurate perceptual evaluation and optimization for image compression.
method: Use pretrained VLMs to produce perceptual judgments (e.g., pairwise preference scores or embedding distances) that correlate with human binary comparisons.
Incorporate the VLM-derived judge as a loss or evaluation metric to guide training/selection of compression models toward outputs preferred by humans.
Validate agreement with human studies and demonstrate improved visual quality (according to human judgments) at matched bitrates versus MSE-optimized baselines.
impact: Provides a scalable, off-the-shelf route to make compression architectures human-aligned without massive psychophysical data collection, enabling practitioners to optimize for perceived quality rather than pixel error.

paper_title: VLIC: Vision-Language Models As Perceptual Judges for Human-Aligned Image Compression
paper_authors: Kyle Sargent, Ruiqi Gao, Philipp Henzler, Charles Herrmann, Aleksander Holynski
